speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And basically, we don't have exact values, but we have some uncertainty around our parameters.

speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So given the observations,

speaker: SPEAKER_04

speaker: SPEAKER_04

So this is kind of the... But how do we approach it?
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: How can we approach it?
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And in a sense, there are a lot of similar projects in various programming languages as well, and they try to solve the same problem in slightly different ways.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: and given that even in this slide there are eight solutions but in reality there are more why do we need a new one why did we decide to write a recent firm where there are so many solutions already developing well the idea here is that for autonomous agents we have a pretty unique set of requirements so if we want to operate in real world
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: We want to have a very big program because a program of a real world is quite complicated, has a lot of parameters, so it should scale.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It also should be low power because our autonomous agents, they usually operate on battery and you don't really want to have an empty battery soon.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So it should preserve energy in the most efficient way.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It should be able to adapt to changes in the environment, because the real environment is chaotic.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It may change, maybe you didn't account for something in your model, so you should be able to change the model on the fly.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It should work in real time, should be as efficient as possible in terms of performance, and it also must be robust.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So we basically are not allowed to stop our computation,
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: it should run and should react to the circumstances.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And this is what ARIS Infer is essentially about and what it tries to achieve.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And in order to achieve this, it combines these three main ideas, also in the literature, factor graphs, variational inference, and reactive message passing.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So these are the three key elements
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: to then we basically try to understand here if we combine them, can we have these properties that I mentioned?
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And so to talk a little bit about each of them.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So a factor graph is essentially a graph representation of a probabilistic model.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And a good thing about factor graphs is that they are explainable and they're not a black box.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So we can clearly see the structure of the model and dependencies in different parameters or hidden states and also observations.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And it's also modular, local, we can reuse certain pieces and we can write specialized computations for certain pieces.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So in RxInfer, we have a special language to write such programs.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So I've got this atModel macro that takes the textual description of a probabilistic model and basically creates a factor graph under it.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So a user should not create those graphs by hand and it doesn't automate.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And we can also create submodules, submodules
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: and we can reuse them in a bigger context.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And as I mentioned, we can, for example, do some local optimizations in our model because we clearly know the structure of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So variation inference, I assume that most of you may be familiar, but for most of you who are not, that's basically an optimization procedure that approximates basically
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So Bayes' rule in many situations is very challenging to solve directly.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So variational inference is a very clever technique to trade off accuracy and maybe solve the task a bit easier at the cost of accuracy.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And also it's faster because you don't have to solve the original problem exactly.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So the formula actually looks a bit more complex than
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: base rule itself.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: But yeah, the math is sometimes strange.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And in practice, it's actually easier to solve this problem than the original math.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So instead of solving the base rule directly, we approximate the result with a simpler set of distributions from exponential family results, for example, which makes it simple.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And we have also language for constraints for the variation
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So sometimes we want to make a mean field over our hidden states, and maybe for some specific states want to be a Gaussian.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So a user also can specify different constraints for different procedure.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And the last thing in our recipe is reactive message passing, which is a central part of the project.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Each message carries a small piece of information required to solve this very complex math behind the inference procedure.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And essentially, in traditional message passing algorithms, they require a fixed global schedule, which has a lot of downsides.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And in a recent ,, we allow messages to flow asynchronously.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And each node in the graph simply reacts on changes
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: anything in the neighborhood can recompense the result locally.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And it's more robust because if part of the system doesn't work, we simply stop reacting.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: But also it, in principle, supports variable update rates for different variables.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: For example, audio signals, they may update at a higher rate than videos.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So the problem with non-conjugate inference in message passing lies in the fact that in order to compute a message, we need to compute an integral.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And in general, computing an integral is not possible on a computer.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: I'm talking about indefinite integrals that have no boundaries.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So for an integral that has a boundary from A to B,
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: say you multiply integral from A to B, you can decompose it into regions and then solve this integral numerically.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: But for unbounded integrals that take from minus infinity to infinity, basically it is impossible, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Because we have a finite memory of computers and you can always create a counter example where it doesn't work.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And it's even worse in
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: in multidimensional spaces, so-called cursive dimensionality.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And this is why people are coming with many clever methods to take those integrals via sampling.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So sampling is essentially an algorithm to take an integral.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So with non-conjugate inference... So let me phrase it the other way around.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So with conjugate inference,
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Those integrals, they can actually be simplified to an exact formula.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So you don't really need to solve the original integral.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: You solve a much simpler problem because you can rearrange some terms and something just cancels out and you get the exact answer.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: If it's not conjugate inference, you cannot do that in general.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So you need to actually solve this integral.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And here is why you need those approximation methods like sampling or projection, which essentially try to solve this problem, but at the cost of accuracy, because we cannot afford infinite memory in our computer.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Awesome.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I see.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So if I just try and... So it effectively boils down to clever ways to compute integrals in ways that it's not going to take too long.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_04
